content.text: Once upon a time, in a peaceful green valley nestled between rolling hills, there lived a kind and gentle shepherd named Thomas.
Thomas took great care of his flock of woolly sheep, making sure they had the freshest grass to eat and the clearest streams to drink from.
Every evening, as the sun dipped below the horizon, painting the sky with hues of pink and gold, Thomas would lead his sheep back to their cozy pen, where they would bleat softly and settle down for
the night. Now, not far from Thomas’s pasture, deep in the shadowy heart of the Darkwood Forest, there lived a wolf named Reginald.
Reginald was not like the other wolves—he was clever, cunning, and always looking for an easy meal. He had watched Thomas’s flock for many days, his mouth watering at the thought of
tender lamb chops. But the sheep were always guarded by Thomas’s sharp-eyed sheepdog, Bruno, and the sturdy fence around the pen.
Reginald knew he could never sneak past Bruno, so he hatched a wicked plan. One misty morning, as the first light of dawn crept over the hills, Reginald slunk through the underbrush until he came
across a small, abandoned farm. There, hanging on a clothesline, was a sheepskin—soft, white, and fluffy, left behind by a careless shepherd. Reginald’s eyes gleamed with mischief.
He snatched the sheepskin, draped it over his own shaggy gray fur, and tied it securely with vines. When he looked at his reflection in a nearby puddle, he barely recognized himself!
With a sly grin, he trotted toward Thomas’s pasture, his paws silent on the dew-covered grass. As Reginald approached the flock, the sheep lifted their heads in curiosity.
They had never seen this new sheep before, but he looked just like them—round and woolly, with gentle eyes.
The lambs bleated happily and nuzzled against him, thinking he was a friend. Even Bruno, the sheepdog, gave Reginald a sniff but wagged his tail, convinced by the disguise.
Reginald’s heart pounded with excitement. *This was too easy!* That evening, as Thomas led his flock back to the pen, Reginald trotted along with the others, his belly rumbling.
The sheep jostled and bleated, eager to return home, and Reginald blended in perfectly. Thomas counted his sheep one by one, patting each on the head as they passed through the gate.
"One, two, three… twenty-nine, thirty!" he said with a smile. "All present and accounted for!" Little did he know that the thirtieth "sheep" was actually a wolf in disguise.

As night fell, the sheep curled up in their pen, their soft wool keeping them warm. Reginald, however, had other plans. He waited until the moon was high in the sky, casting long, eerie shadows across
the pasture. Then, with a wicked gleam in his eye, he crept toward the fattest, juiciest lamb in the flock. But just as he was about to pounce—*SNAP!*—a twig broke beneath his paw.
Bruno, who had been dozing nearby, lifted his head instantly. His ears pricked up, and his nose twitched. Something was wrong.
He sniffed the air and caught a scent that didn’t belong—a scent that was wild and dangerous. With a low growl, Bruno leaped to his feet and stared straight at Reginald.
The wolf froze, his heart racing. He tried to look innocent, but Bruno wasn’t fooled. With a fierce bark, the sheepdog lunged at Reginald, his teeth bared.

Reginald yelped in terror and bolted, the sheepskin flapping behind him as he ran. He dashed through the pasture, leaped over the fence, and didn’t stop until he was deep in the Darkwood Forest, where
the trees swallowed him whole. Bruno chased him to the edge of the pasture but knew his duty was to protect the flock. With one last warning growl, he turned back to guard the sheep.
The next morning, Thomas found the sheepskin tangled in the bushes near the fence. He picked it up, his brow furrowed in confusion. "How strange," he murmured.
"This must have blown in from somewhere." He looked around but saw no sign of danger. Still, he decided to check on his flock extra carefully that day.
As he counted the sheep, he noticed Bruno sitting a little straighter, his ears alert. "Good boy," Thomas said, scratching the dog behind his ears. "You kept them safe, didn’t you?"
From that day on, Reginald never dared to come near Thomas’s flock again. He slunk back to the Darkwood Forest, where he told the other wolves about his failed plan.
They laughed at him, calling him a fool for thinking he could outsmart a sheepdog. Reginald hung his head in shame, but deep down, he knew he had learned a valuable lesson: *trickery
might work for a little while, but the truth always comes out in the end.* And so, Thomas and his sheep lived happily ever after, their days filled with sunshine, green grass, and the comforting
knowledge that Bruno was always watching over them. As for Reginald? Well, he stuck to hunting rabbits and squirrels—much safer, and far less trouble!
And now, my dear child, it’s time for you to close your eyes and drift off to sleep, just like the sheep in their cozy pen.
Dream of gentle meadows, loyal sheepdogs, and kind shepherds who keep you safe. Goodnight.
